questions.text: Aortic aneurysms caused by spondyloarthropathies are most commonly seen in:
questions.solution:
Aortic aneurysms caused by spondyloarthropathies are most commonly seen in the ascending aorta.

An aneurysm is a pathologic dilation of a segment of a blood vessel. An aortic aneurysm occurs when the structural components of the aortic wall, that is, elastin and collagen, are damaged. This may occur either due to degradation or abnormal synthesis of these components.

The causes of aneurysm are as follows:

questions.text: What is the most common pathology associated with ascending aortic aneurysm?
questions.solution:
The most common pathology associated with ascending aortic aneurysm is medial degeneration.

Medial degeneration (cystic medial necrosis) describes the degenerative process of the tunica media of the aorta. There is degeneration of collagen and elastic fibers in the media and loss of medial cells that are replaced by multiple clefts of mucoid material, such as proteoglycans.

It is seen in the following conditions and is associated with the corresponding mutations:

  • Marfan’s syndrome- fibrillin 1
  • Loeys-Dietz syndrome- TGFBR1, TGFBR2
  • Ehlers-Danlos syndrome type IV - type III procollagen
  • Familial thoracic aortic aneurysm syndromes- genes associated with actin and myosin eg. ACTA2, MHC11
  • Congenital bicuspid aortic valves
  • Turner’s syndrome
  • Hypertension

questions.text: A 40-year-old man who is a known case of Marfan's syndrome has come for his regular check-up. His chest X-ray is shown below. Following this, he is being taken up for echocardiography to evaluate the given finding further. Which of the following is true regarding the management of this patient?

choices.text: Operative repair if diameter is > 5 cm
Operative repair if diameter is > 6 cm
Operative repair if diameter is > 5.5 cm
Operative repair if diameter is > 4 cm

questions.solution:
The X-ray shows a widening of the mediastinum with trachea displaced to the right and dilatation of the ascending thoracic aorta (red arrow) i.e. ascending thoracic aortic aneurysm. In the case of Marfan's syndrome, ascending aortic aneurysm of 4-5 cm is taken up for operative repair. This is because of a higher rate of expansion of the aneurysm in these patients.

Management of thoracic aortic aneurysm:

  • Beta-blockers and angiotensin receptor antagonists reduce the rate of expansion, especially in Marfan's syndrome.
  • Operative treatment is indicated in:
    • All symptomatic cases
    • Ascending aortic aneurysm - ≥ 5.5 cm in diameter or growth rate of >0.5 cm/year
    • Descending aortic aneurysm - > 6 cm in diameter or growth rate of >1 cm/year
    • Marfan's syndrome - 4-5 cm in diameter

questions.text: A 50-year-old man came with complaints of irregular bowel movements. While undergoing an abdominal ultrasound examination, an abdominal aortic aneurysm of 5.8 cm diameter was noted. There is a history of hyperlipidemia for the past 10 years. What is the next best step in the management of AAA?

choices.text: Follow up with serial abdominal ultrasound

questions.solution:
Operative repair of the aneurysm is the next best step in management in this case. Operative repair is indicated for both symptomatic or asymptomatic abdominal aortic aneurysms if they are ≥ 5.5 cm in diameter.

Abdominal aortic aneurysms are mostly asymptomatic and are detected as incidental findings on investigations for other complaints. Sometimes, they present with pain and pulsatile abdominal mass. Rupture of aneurysm presents with acute pain and hypotension.

Management of abdominal aortic aneurysms:

  • Statins- atherosclerosis is the most common pathology associated with abdominal aortic aneurysms. Hence, statins are prescribed to reduce the risk of cardiovascular events.
  • Asymptomatic aneurysms <5.5 cm in diameter- serial abdominal ultrasound to monitor the rate of expansion of the aneurysm.
  • Operative repair is indicated for:
    • Aneurysm of any size associated with symptoms
    • Rapidly growing aneurysms
    • Aneurysms ≥5.5 cm in diameter

Note: Medical management with beta-blockers though helps in BP control, it is not effective in reducing the rate of growth of abdominal aortic aneurysms.

questions.text: A 55-year-old patient came to the OPD with a complaint of abdominal pain. On further investigations, he was found to have an abdominal aortic aneurysm. Which of the following investigations may indicate the etiology of the aneurysm?
questions.solution:
Blood cultures may indicate the etiology of the aneurysm. They are often positive in patients with mycotic aneurysms.

A mycotic aneurysm is a rare condition that develops as a result of staphylococcal, streptococcal, salmonella or other bacterial or fungal infections of the aorta. The term mycotic aneurysm is usually a misnomer as the causative pathogen is usually bacteria rather than fungi.

These aneurysms are usually saccular. These organisms may involve every major artery, but aortic involvement predominates.

questions.text: All of the following are predisposing factors for aortic dissection, except:
questions.solution:
The third trimester of pregnancy is a predisposing factor for aortic dissection, not second.

Predisposition to aortic dissection increases when there are factors associated with:

  • Medial degeneration- seen in:
    • Syndromes affecting the connective tissue- Marfan's, Ehlers Danlos syndrome
    • Vasculitis- Takayasu's arteritis, giant cell arteritis
  • Increased stress on the aortic wall- seen in:
    • Hypertension
    • Third trimester of pregnancy
  • Other conditions with increased incidence include:
    • Bicuspid aortic valve
    • Coarctation of aorta
    • Aortic trauma
    • Cocaine use

questions.text: A 65-year-old man presents with acute pain in the chest which radiates to the interscapular region of the back. He is a known hypertensive for the past 10 years. His CT is shown below. Which of the following drug is contraindicated in this patient?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the CT image showing double-lumen of the aorta are suggestive of aortic dissection. Isolated use of a direct vasodilator such as hydralazine is contraindicated in acute dissection.

It is because these agents can increase hydraulic shear and worsen the dissection by causing vasodilation without reducing the left ventricular ejection force that continues to weaken the arterial wall. 

Medical therapy for aortic dissection includes beta-blockers and sodium nitroprusside to reduce cardiac contractility and blood pressure. The heart rate is reduced to around 60 bpm and the SBP is lowered to ≤ 120mmHg.

CCBs like verapamil and diltiazem may be used IV if nitroprusside or beta-blockers cannot be employed. Parenteral angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE) inhibitor such as enalaprilat may be considered.

questions.text: The image depicting Stanford type A aortic dissection is?
questions.solution:
Image D depicts Stanford type A aortic dissection.

The classification schemes for aortic dissection are:

  • Stanford classification
    • Type A - dissection involves the ascending aorta with or without the involvement of other parts of the aorta
    • Type B - dissection is limited to the arch and/or descending aorta without the involvement of ascending aorta
  • DeBakey classification
    • Type I - dissection involves ascending to descending aorta
    • Type II - dissection is limited to the ascending aorta or transverse aorta without descending aorta
    • Type III - intimal tear is located in the descending aorta with distal propagation of the dissection

 

Hence, if the ascending aorta is involved, it is Stanford type A and DeBakey type I or II. If only the aortic arch or the descending aorta is involved, it is Stanford type B and DeBakey type III.

From a management standpoint, the classification of aortic dissections into type A or B is more practical and useful, since DeBakey types I and II are managed in a similar manner.

questions.text: A 50-year-old man presents with a history of severe pain and numbness in his calf muscles following morning walks. The symptoms subside on taking rest. On examination, thickened toenails, decreased pulses, and reduced temperature of the legs are noted. He has a history of smoking for the past  20 years. Which of the following is the most appropriate advice for this patient?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario describes intermittent claudication. It is the most common symptom of peripheral arterial disease (PAD). The most appropriate advice for this patient is antiplatelet therapy with aspirin.

PAD occurs due to atherosclerotic plaques causing stenosis and occlusion of blood flow. The symptoms of inadequate blood flow exacerbate during increased physical activity.

The following advice is given to patients with PAD:

  • Lifestyle modification- regular exercise, discontinue smoking
  • Statins to treat hypercholesterolemia
  • Reducing the risk of cardiovascular events:
    • Controlling hypertension- angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitors, angiotensin receptor blockers, beta-blockers
    • Antiplatelet therapy- aspirin, clopidogrel
  • Revascularization procedures (catheter-based or surgical)- For patients not improving with medical therapy
    • Endovascular interventions- percutaneous transluminal balloon angioplasty (PTA), stent placement, atherectomy
    • Surgical- aortobifemoral bypass using Dacron grafts, axillofemoral bypass, femoro-femoral bypass

Antiplatelet therapy and warfarin is not preferred because of the high risk of bleeding.

Intravenous heparin is used to treat acute limb ischemia which most often occurs due to thromboembolic events. Acute limb ischemia presents with loss of pulses distal to the occlusion, cyanosis, or pallor. These symptoms do not subside on taking rest. Hence, this patient has intermittent claudication and not acute limb ischemia.

questions.text: Which of the following collagen vascular diseases has the strongest association with Raynaud’s phenomenon?
questions.solution:
Among the given collagen vascular diseases, systemic sclerosis has the strongest association with Raynaud’s phenomenon.

Raynaud’s phenomenon occurs in:

  • 80–90% of patients with systemic sclerosis (scleroderma).
  • 20% of patients with systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE).
  • 30% of patients with dermatomyositis or polymyositis.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman complains of bluish discoloration of her fingertips on exposure to cold. Which of the following drugs should be avoided in this patient?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Raynaud’s phenomenon. Clonidine is avoided in Raynaud’s phenomenon as it worsens the condition.

Clonidine acts on central alpha-2 adrenoreceptor in CNS and reduces sympathetic outflow. This causes decreased blood pressure and perfusion that can exacerbate Raynaud's phenomenon or any PVD.

Drugs that can be used for the treatment of Raynaud’s phenomenon:

Primary Raynaud's:

  • Dihydropyridine CCBs- nifedipine, isradipine, felodipine, and amlodipine
  • Diltiazem
  • Prazosin, doxazosin, and terazosin

Secondary Raynaud's:

  • Phosphodiesterase type 5 inhibitors- sildenafil and tadalafil

Digital sympathectomy is helpful in some patients who are unresponsive to medical therapy.
